awd_titl_txt: CAREER - Building the Vertebrate Body with Axial Stem Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
The human body plan, along with the body plan of all other vertebrates, is established during embryogenesis in a progressive manner, with the head forming first and the rest of the body growing sequentially away from the head. Recent work in vertebrate animal models revealed the unexpected finding that a population of stem cells, called axial stem cells, fuels the process of body growth over long periods of time by contributing new cells to the differentiating spinal cord, skeletal muscle, and blood vessels, among others. Since axial stem cells have only recently been discovered, there is a severe paucity of information regarding their normal development in any species. The goal of this project is to establish the molecular mechanisms of axial stem cell induction, maintenance, and fate specification in the zebrafish.  This work will provide critical insight into how the vertebrate body is created, as well as shed light on the mechanisms leading to body plan diversity across the animal kingdom. Undergraduate students will participate in this project, providing them with a cutting edge research experience. Additionally, the project will also use zebrafish as a tool to teach biological principles to high school students, and to get them excited about developmental biology. This will be accomplished through two mechanisms: 1) the creation of a professional development course for high school teachers that will provide them with the training necessary to run zebrafish development teaching laboratories at their schools, and 2) a hands-on laboratory module for high school students. These programs are designed to meet the needs of the changing emphasis on laboratory-based hands on learning, with a particular emphasis on providing these educational opportunities to high-needs school districts.

Zebrafish offer an unparalleled system to investigate axial stem cell biology. The transparent embryos, along with genetic and cell transplantation tools, allow for the precise determination of the cell-autonomous, temporal role of pathways and genes functioning within axial stem cells in vivo. Using these methods, this project investigates three key aspects of axial stem cells, including 1) how axial stem cells are induced during the gastrula stage and maintained after gastrulation in the embryonic tailbud, 2) the mechanism by which the canonical Wnt signaling pathway induces mesoderm within axial stem cells, and 3) how the Sox2 transcription factor promotes neural induction in axial stem cells.

por.por_cntn:
The human body plan is established during early development in a progressive fashion where the head forms first and the rest of the body is formed sequentially over time. This mode of development is conserved across all vertebrate species, and thus this aspect of human development can be modeled using vertebrate laboratory animals. In this project we used the vertebrate Danio rerio, commonly called the zebrafish, as a model system to study body plan development. We focused on a population of cells at the posterior-most end of the extending embryo previously called axial stem cells and now generally referred to as neuromesodermal progenitors (NMPs). NMPs exhibit a large degree of plasticity and can give rise to either neural tissue or mesoderm depending on the local signaling environment, allowing for the addition of new differentiated cells to tissues such as the spinal cord and skeletal muscle.

 

Intellectual merit: There were three main goals of this project including 1) understanding how NMPs are induced and later maintained in an undifferentiated state, 2) determining how mesoderm is induced from NMPs and later patterned into different cell types, and 3) understanding how neural fate is induced from NMPs. Our work addressing these goals resulted in 15 peer reviewed research and review articles and we discovered several new aspects related to NMP biology and vertebrate body plan development. We identified an important signaling pathway that induces the NMPs during early development, as well as other pathways that maintain them in an undifferentiated state as the body forms. The allocation of NMPs to particular tissue types is due to a fine balance between certain molecular factors, and when the balance is tipped in one direction or the other the NMPs commit to neural or mesodermal tissue. During the formation of mesoderm, there is a biological checkpoint that ensures that neural tissue is not mistakenly generated in regions where mesoderm normally forms. The checkpoint holds cells in the posterior of the embryo and prevents them from exiting into the mesodermal territory until they have repressed any neural inducing factors. Once cells commit to mesoderm and exit, they encounter additional signals that direct them to either a skeletal muscle or blood vessel fate. These two tissues continue to interact with signals from and shape changes within the skeletal muscle, which promotes the proper patterning and organization of the major blood vessels of the embryonic body.  

 

Several new research tools and methods were developed as part of this project and are now available to the scientific community. The tools include new transgenic zebrafish strains that allow manipulation of signaling pathways or specific genes, detection of the cell cycle state of each cell in the developing embryo, and ablation of the embryonic skeletal muscle. Some of the new methods include techniques for live-imaging of developing embryos and improvements to detection of specific molecules in an embryo.  

 

Broader Impacts: Many high school, undergraduate, and graduate students were trained in using zebrafish as a model system, molecular biology techniques, developmental biology theory, and data analysis and interpretation. These students have gone on to further study biology and medicine and to biologist jobs in academia and industry. Six of the high school students were chosen as Regeneron Science Talent Search Scholars and one  as a Regeneron Science Talent Search Finalist. One postdoctoral fellow was also trained during the course of this project. The project provided professional development to NY state secondary school teachers through the creation and teaching of a developmental biology mini-course. This was done as part of the NY State Master’s Teaching Program, which is a statewide mechanism to provide professional development for science and math teachers. The course was taught on the Stony Brook University campus and attended by local Long Island teachers and was also recorded for live web-cast and archival viewing. We also organized the first ever neuromesodermal progenitor scientific meeting, which was held online and had presentations from scientists working on various aspects of neuromesodermal progenitor biology from around the world.
